title: The Dow Dropped 142 Points Because Trump Is Contending With Impeachment, China, and Iran
text:
Text size

Downdraft. All three main stock indexes gave up gains and ended in the red. Speaking to the United Nations General Assembly, President Donald Trump said he won’t accept a bad trade deal with China and called for all nations to act on Iran. Trump also said he’ll release the complete transcript of his conversation with Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky as House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced an impeachment inquiry against Trump. In today’s After the Bell, we...

Simmering Pressure

Stocks closed with losses on Tuesday, as investors cautiously watch the development of multiple political events. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has dropped 142.22 points, or 0.53%, to close at 26,807.77. The S&P 500 fell 25.18 points, or 0.84%, to finish at 2966.60, and the Nasdaq Composite lost 118.83 points, or 1.46%, to close at 7993.63.

U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer are scheduled to meet with Chinese Vice Premier He Liu for trade talks in two weeks.

Beijing has reportedly issued waivers to several domestic companies to buy American soybeans without being subject to retaliatory tariffs. Still, the major disputes between the two countries remain unsolved and it’s unclear whether an interim deal will be reached at the high-level meeting.

Speaking to the U.N. General Assembly today, President Trump listed a series of accusations against Beijing’s “unfair practices,” including currency manipulation, heavy state subsidies, and intellectual property theft. “Hopefully we can reach an agreement that will be beneficial for both countries,” Trump said. “But as I have said, I will not accept a bad deal.”

Editor's Choice

Trump also slammed Iran’s alleged role in the attacks on Saudi oil facilities during his U.N. speech, calling world leaders to pressure Tehran into diplomatic talks. “No responsible government should subsidize Iran’s blood lust, “ said Trump. “As long as Iran’s menacing behavior continues, sanctions will not be lifted, they will be tightened.”

France, Germany, and the U.K. also issued a joint statement on Tuesday, joining the U.S. in blaming Iran for the Saudi attack and urging Tehran to start negotiating a new deal that would be more comprehensive than the 2015 one, from which President Trump withdrew last year. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani and Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif said the country is open to discussions for a new deal, if the U.S. lifted sanctions on the country.

On hopes of possible solutions to the region’s geopolitical tension, crude prices fell on Tuesday despite concerns over Saudi’s output recovery following the attack. The global benchmark Brent crude fell 2.58% to $63.10 a barrel on Tuesday, while the West Texas Intermediate dropped 2.30% to $57.29 a barrel.

Elsewhere, consumer confidence declined sharply to 125.1 in September, falling far short of economists’ expectations for 133.3, and hitting a three-month low. “Over much of the past year, consumers have remained relatively upbeat in their views, despite the obvious slowdown in the economy and the simmering relationship with China,” wrote Jim Baird at Plante Moran Financial Advisors on Tuesday. “Even so, gauges of confidence have been as volatile as the state of trade negotiations over that time, rising and falling as the prospects for an agreement with China evolved.”

Despite the falling sentiment, household spending remained positive, and that’s especially key at this stage, given that business investment and trade conflict are both weighing on the economy. “For now, the consumer sector has been resilient and the spillover from other parts of the economy has been contained,” wrote Baird. “For the economy to continue to power ahead, that will need to continue.”
